sub_bullets.text: Describe the Agile values and principles and explain how they differ from traditional project management approaches.
Understand how to plan and manage sprints, including defining sprint goals, estimating tasks, and setting realistic timelines.
Understand the concept of delivering in increments, gathering customer feedback after each iteration, and using it to improve the product and plan future work.

characteristics.text: Works best when a project doesn’t have clear constraints, timelines, or available resources

sub_bullets.text: Each phase follows a cycle, changing based on progress as well as user and stakeholder needs
Quick turnover
Everyone is responsible for the success of the initiative
Analyze concept and requirements
Determine current state and expectations
Arrange teams and tools
Break project into small manageable tasks
Set KPIs (key performance indicators)
Choose a project management system (Notion, Trello, etc.) to keep track of everything
Map user and stakeholders needs to product features, prototyping.
Visualize your product and how it will function in the real world
Manufacturing, software development, i.e. fulfill steps needed to produce the “product”
Ensure product functions as intended, address issues/concerns
Plan, design, and development may change during this step
Conduct interviews, run scenarios, internal testing
Present product to stakeholders
Push product to market, start tracking KPIs
Collect feedback
Reflect on KPIs and feedback
Repeat Agile cycle

benefits.text: You can deploy to market quickly, which allows you to get feedback and responses in a short span
You waste fewer resources (including time) because you always work on up-to-date tasks
Short “sprints” allow you to detect and fix issues and defects faster

drawbacks.text: Short “sprints” do not leave time for documentation, which makes it difficult to avoid repeating past mistakes
Short cycles don’t leave enough time for the design thinking process

example.text: Project team at Hack4Impact, a UMD club that creates technical solutions for nonprofit clients
The card demonstrates the plan and design steps

sub_bullets.text: The picture is the prototype
The plan are the bullets outlining the functionality and technologies

example.text: Testing takes place when the card goes to the “Verification” section
Deployment and Review takes place when card goes to “Done” section

evaluation.text: What are the steps of agile
Test your knowledge by listing 3 pros of agile for a project of your choice
